newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek shares give up gains, close off session lows.
newsitem.headline: Greek shares give up gains, close off session lows.

text.p: Volatile construction shares, banks and small-caps gave up some of their recent gains as Greek shares spent the session in negative territory before closing above session lows in moderate turnover.

"Players are tuned in but the market is directionless right now, anticipating possible tax measures and the 1997 budget. This doesn't mean it isn't a time for selective buying. I see stocks staging a gradual climb in the short term," said portfolio manager Marilena Vasiloglou at ABN AMRO Mutual funds.
"We are about 80 percent invested but retain adequate liquidity to pounce on opportunities. We like banks and food stocks, they are more defensive," she said.

Financial press reports that the government is planning to tax interest earned on T-bills, derivatives such as swaps, options and FRAs and revamp the tax status of mutual funds, finds the market cautious as players await the 1997 budget.
The finance ministry announced a 40 basis point cut in the marker 12-month T-bill. It will come down to 12.30 percent in the end-October issue.
On Tuesday, block trades in National Mortgage Bank, NIBID, National Housing Bank and Sarantis boosted trading volume to 50.21 billion drachmas. They were attributable to National Bank.
"National Bank was trying to create sufficient capital gains to offset 63 billion drachmas of losses from a single write off of bad loans, scheduled for the second half of 1996," said ING Barings.

"This should do away with most of National's portfolio of bad, politically motivated loans. The write-off is a brave move aimed at cleaning up its balance sheet which is difficult to see through," it said.
